title: 108_s1147
content: The Act is titled the "High-Tech Port Security Act of 2003" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "High-Tech Port Security Act of 2003" defines key terms such as Captain-of-the-Port, Container, Blast-resistant container, and Regulated container. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, and "vessel" is defined as per section 401 of the Tariff Act of 1930. SEC. 101. BLAST-RESISTANT CONTAINERS. Regulations will be established by the Secretary within 90 days of the Act's enactment for the certification of blast-resistant containers. Interested parties can apply for certification by submitting prototypes and cost estimates. Vessels carrying regulated containers entering the US must have all containers certified as blast-resistant 15 months after the regulations are prescribed. The Secretary will evaluate each application for certification. The Secretary will evaluate applications for certification of blast-resistant containers within 90 days of submission. Certification must be completed within 15 months of the regulations being prescribed. The Secretary will deny entry of a vessel into the United States if regulated containers are not certified. The deadline may be extended for up to 1 year if economically feasible prototypes are not available. A report must be submitted to relevant committees. The deadline for entry into the US may be extended for up to 1 year if economically feasible prototypes are not available. Representatives must submit a report detailing the reasons for the extension and steps needed to ensure prototypes exist before the new deadline. SEC. 102. SCREENING PRIOR TO DEPARTURE FROM PORT. Regulations will be established within 90 days of the Act's enactment for certifying equipment to screen containers for radioactive and explosive materials before leaving US ports. Every container entering the US by vessel must undergo screening for such materials before departure, starting 15 months after the regulations are set. The Secretary will assess each certification application. The Secretary will evaluate certification applications for screening equipment within 90 days of submission. Screening containers for radioactive and explosive materials is required before departure from US ports, starting 15 months after regulations are established. The Secretary will ensure that the 20 largest ports and other vulnerable ports deploy certified screening equipment within 15 months of regulations being established. All other US ports must also deploy such equipment promptly. The Secretary will require screening for radioactive and explosive materials in containers at the 20 largest ports and other highly vulnerable ports in the US within 15 months of regulations being established. SEC. 201. COMMAND AND CONTROL CENTERS. The Secretary must establish command and control centers at the 20 largest ports in the US within 90 days of the Act. A grant program will provide funds for this purpose to port authorities, facility operators, and state and local agencies. Each entity seeking a grant under this subsection must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. Authorization of Appropriations: $100,000,000 is authorized to the Secretary for carrying out this Act.
